title: 108_hr4604
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Protecting Railroads against Enemy Efforts through Modernization, Planning, and Technology Act" and includes a Railroad Transportation Security Plan. The "Protecting Railroads against Enemy Efforts through Modernization, Planning, and Technology Act" requires the Secretary of Transportation to develop a security plan for the Nation's railroads, including identifying critical assets, threats, vulnerabilities related to hazardous materials transportation, and backup systems for continued operation. The security plan for the Nation's railroads includes identifying security weaknesses in passenger and cargo security, transportation infrastructure, protection systems, procedural policies, communications systems, employee training, and emergency response planning. It also involves developing a plan for increased security support at high threat levels in consultation with railroads and State/local governments. The security plan for the Nation's railroads includes procedures for establishing consultative relations among parties, a contingency plan for continued movement of freight and passengers in case of an attack affecting the railroad system, including rerouting traffic and ensuring service in the Northeast Corridor. The security plan for the Nation's railroads includes procedures for establishing consultative relations among parties, a contingency plan for continued movement of freight and passengers in case of an attack affecting the railroad system, including rerouting traffic and ensuring service in the Northeast Corridor. The plan shall consider existing public and private sector efforts to address security issues and develop recommendations for improving railroad security, focusing on rail tunnels, bridges, switching areas, infrastructure, facilities, and information systems. The security plan for the Nation's railroads includes deploying equipment to detect explosives and hazardous substances, installing redundant systems for continued operation during attacks, and conducting public outreach campaigns. The security plan for the Nation's railroads includes public outreach campaigns, deploying surveillance equipment, and identifying costs for addressing risks. The Secretary of Transportation will consult with various stakeholders in developing the plan and must report to the Committee on Commerce, Science, and within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Transportation will submit a report to the Senate and House committees containing prioritized recommendations and cost estimates for implementing security measures for railroads. The report may be submitted in classified or redacted formats if deemed necessary. $10,000,000 is authorized for the Secretary of Transportation for fiscal year 2005 to carry out these measures. SEC. 3. MEMORANDUM OF UNDERSTANDING. The Secretary of Transportation and the Secretary of Homeland Security will execute a memorandum of understanding within 180 days to govern their roles in addressing railroad security, promoting communication, efficiency, and avoiding duplication of efforts. SEC. 4. RAILROAD SECURITY UPGRADES. Security Improvement Grants are authorized by the Secretary of Transportation for various entities to prevent or respond to acts of terrorism, sabotage, or other railroad security threats. This includes funding for automated security inspection, communications-based train control systems, emergency bridge repair technology, track monitoring, tank car vulnerability reduction, and bridge and tunnel inspection demonstrations. The Security Improvement Grants cover various areas such as bridge and tunnel inspection technologies, national railroad emergency operations center, signal system security, critical communications redundancy, hazardous material transportation security, passenger railroad station security, public awareness campaigns, intelligence sharing on security threats, and train tracking with interoperable communications. Authorization of Appropriations: 
- $5,000,000 for automated security inspection in fiscal years 2005 and 2006
- $20,000,000 for train control systems development and deployment
- $5,000,000 for emergency bridge repair technology in fiscal years 2005 through 2008
- $3,000,000 for track and structure improvements in fiscal year 2005 In fiscal year 2005, appropriations include $3,000,000 for track, structure, and right-of-way monitoring, $3,000,000 for tank car vulnerability reduction technologies, $20,000,000 for bridge and tunnel inspection technologies, $10,000,000 for a national railroad emergency operations center, $1,500,000 for signal system security at turnouts, and $350,000,000 for various purposes outlined in subsection (a). Amounts appropriated will remain available until expended. SEC. 5. FIRE AND LIFE-SAFETY IMPROVEMENTS. The Secretary of Transportation is authorized to procure fire and life-safety improvements for tunnels on the Northeast Corridor in New York, Baltimore, and Washington, D.C. Appropriations are authorized for ventilation, electrical, and fire safety upgrades, emergency communication systems, and passenger access improvements for the New York tunnels. For fiscal years 2005-2009, funding is allocated for upgrades to tunnels in Baltimore, Potomac, and Union Station in Washington, D.C. This includes improvements in drainage, ventilation, communication, lighting, and passenger egress. For fiscal years 2008 and 2009, $8,000,000 is allocated for upgrades to tunnels in Baltimore, Potomac, and Union Station in Washington, D.C. Appropriated funds shall remain available until expended. SEC. 6. MISCELLANEOUS TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING PROVISIONS. Rail Police Officers will now have authority over any rail carrier. The Secretary of Transportation will review rail regulations within a year to enhance railroad security. Amendments are made to include security in railroad safety regulations. The Transportation Security Administration personnel limitations do not apply to employees responsible for implementing security measures under this Act. The term "railroad" in this Act is defined as per section 20102 of title 49, United States Code.
